description.plain:
Tyler Gregory Okonma (born March 6, 1991), better known as Tyler, The Creator, is a rapper, singer, record producer, video director, stylist, TV writer and actor from California. He first received major recognition in the hip-hop community in the early 2010s as a founding member of the rap collective, Odd Future.

Known for his explosive personality and absurdist lyrical content, Tyler released his debut mixtape, Bastard in 2009. Subsequent releases were his debut studio album, Goblin, in 2011 under XL Recordings, Wolf in 2013 under Odd Future Records, Cherry Bomb in 2015, and released Flower Boy in 2017 under Columbia Records. In November 2018, he released Music Inspired by Illumination & Dr. Seuss' The Grinch, a 6-track EP inspired from his work with Illumination’s movie The Grinch. Most recently, in May 2019 he released IGOR, an album with a unique sound compared to his other work and was his first project to win a Grammy, as he took home the award for Best Rap Album. It also became his first project to top the Billboard 200.

He has also his own fashion brand called Golf Wang and has created two comedic television programs for the late-night programming block Adult Swim: the sketch series, Loiter Squad, and the animated show, The Jellies.

songs.full_title: Yonkers by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: Yonkers

description.plain:
“Yonkers” is the first single off Tyler, The Creator’s debut album, Goblin and is widely considered as his breakout song.

The song’s title is named after the city of Yonkers, New York. Tyler said that the song made was as a joke to mimic New York hip-hop beats:

Dude, niggas don’t know that that beat was made as a joke. I was trying to make a shitty New York beat and we was just rapping like we was from New York like we were retarded. And then, I just had some random verses and I was just like ‘I’ll just record it to this beat, this beat is kinda cool.’ And then niggas really liked it.

Despite its controversial lyrics, the song became critically acclaimed on release. Its music video earned Tyler the Best New Artist award at the 2011 MTV Video Music Awards. It was also nominated for Video of the Year but lost to Katy Perry’s “Firework.”

songs.full_title: EARFQUAKE by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: EARFQUAKE

description.plain:
“EARFQUAKE” is a collaboration between Tyler, The Creator and Playboi Carti. In the song, Tyler sings about a lover he depends on, who he knows he hasn’t treated the best, but needs. This is done over beautiful, cheery piano chords and heavy, distorted drums, mixing styles from his last two albums, Cherry Bomb and Flower Boy.

In an interview with Rick Rubin on his podcast Broken Record, Tyler explains that his inspiration for the title came from there being an actual earthquake when he was writing the song. Then he decided to change the “th” to an “f.”

During Tyler’s concert hosted by Apple Music with IGOR presentation, Tyler said the song is from 2017, and he wrote it for Justin Bieber, but “he didn’t take it.” It was also offered to Rihanna who also declined.

songs.full_title: See You Again by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Kali Uchis)
songs.title: See You Again

description.plain:
Tyler’s favorite off of Flower Boy, “See You Again” is a love song. The song features vocals from Kali Uchis, who appeared on Tyler’s 2015 album Cherry Bomb on “FIND YOUR WINGS” and “FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT.”

The person Tyler sings to on this song seems to be his ideal lover, as they only live in his fantasy and dream state. Whenever he wakes up this person disappears, and therefore he doesn’t wish to wake up. While he is very much in love with them, he hates constantly waiting and chasing.

The song directly follows the interlude “Sometimes…” where we hear a male voice ask Shane Powers to play the song about him on Golf Radio. What comes next is “See You Again.” This implies that the song is likely about a man.

This was Tyler’s twitter bio a few months before Flower Boy’s release:

https://twitter.com/Tylersbio/status/819583613398196224

Tyler also mentioned that the song was originally written for Zayn Malik on Twitter:

songs.full_title: She by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Frank Ocean)
songs.title: She

description.plain:
“She” is the fourth track off of Tyler’s second studio album Goblin. The song focuses on a man’s intense lust for a woman he watches sleep  and stalks. While the song features soft melodies from Frank Ocean, it is harshly contrasted by Tyler’s graphic lyrics, which center around themes of rape and necrophilia.

The music video for the song debuted on YouTube on July 3rd, 2011 and, as of August 2018, has over 60 million views.

description.plain: “Who Dat Boy” is the first single from Tyler’s Flower Boy album and features close friend and collaborator A$AP Rocky. Their first collaboration was when A$AP Mob featured Tyler on “Telephone Calls.” Rocky was also featured on “WHAT THE FUCK RIGHT NOW,” a remix of Kanye West’s “Freestyle 4” and the last song Tyler released before “Who Dat Boy.” They also went on a tour together in 2015. As said by Tyler at the Agenda Festival, the song was made in as far back as December 2015.

songs.full_title: 911 / Mr. Lonely by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Frank Ocean & Steve Lacy)
songs.title: 911 / Mr. Lonely
songs.title_with_featured: 911 / Mr. Lonely (Ft. Frank Ocean & Steve Lacy)

description.plain:
“911 / Mr. Lonely” is a two part track released as a single along with “Who Dat Boy” on June 30th, 2017. The song is the 10th track on Flower Boy, and features Frank Ocean, Steve Lacy, A$AP Rocky, ScHoolboy Q and Anna of the North. The first half is more upbeat but is filled with dark depressing lyrics. The second half has more depressing lyrics, but with a less upbeat and snare heavy beat. The song was one of the stand-out tracks of Tyler’s critically acclaimed fourth album, Flower Boy.

The beat used in 911 was originally used in Tyler’s 2016 GOLF Fashion Show with further instrumentals and vocals being added and changed.
https://youtu.be/IrdzbRTk1n4?t=5m43s

This song might come as a shock to many fans of Tyler. During the release of Cherry Bomb he stated that he is not depressed anymore and that he wished to ditch “depressing rap”. Because of his transition of rapping about dark, violent and depressing topics to rapping about cars and wealth, Tyler was often criticized by fans of his older material – like Bastard and Goblin. When it comes to content, mood and lyrics, this is more in line with his previous material.

songs.title: Bastard

description.plain:
As the essential introduction to his solo musical personality, Tyler goes back and forth with a fictional psychiatrist denominated “Dr. TC” in the form of nine unmistakably remarkable verses.

This song featured intense charisma, trait that attracted many followers to the Odd Future movement and was widely hailed as one of OFWGKTA’s best musical endeavors. This remarkable admiration from the fans later got referenced in the track “Goblin,” the first track off Tyler’s debut album of same name.

Bastard intro, how the fuck I’m gonna top that?

songs.full_title: Tron Cat by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: Tron Cat

description.plain:
Tron Cat is the first leaked track from Tyler the Creator’s forthcoming Goblin

Tyler adressed it on Twitter
https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/64472160504250369
https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/64472297540562944
As usual, Tyler uses an original beat on this track (except for Radical, did you really expect anything different?).

“Tron Cat” seems to be another of Tyler’s inner voices (he discusses the kitten with his psychiatrist in “Nightmare”)

The title is probably derived from the highly influential “Chappelle’s Show” bit, portraying a black drug dealer called Tron Carter.



The title could also be a reference to musician Thundercat’s cat named “Turbo Tron.” In a Pitchfork interview, Thundercat describes bringing the cat to the OF store opening and Tyler taking an interest in him.

songs.full_title: NEW MAGIC WAND by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: NEW MAGIC WAND

description.plain:
On “NEW MAGIC WAND,” Tyler desperately attempts to convince someone he has feelings for to not leave him. However, the person Tyler is in love with is still thinking about their previous relationship with a woman. In the song, Tyler goes to extreme length such as threatening to kill both his love interest and his love interest’s ex-girlfriend in order to get what he wants.

On September 12, 2020, Tyler determined that “NEW MAGIC WAND” is his best song ever in a tweeted bracket ranking of all his own favorite songs.  The song beat out OKAGA, CA for the number one spot.  Tyler had previously declared it his favorite song on IGOR through Instagram on May 30, 2019.

The song was first teased in a 47-second snippet posted on Tyler’s social media platforms on May 14, 2019. The song opens with grimy beat, and features a soft synth change during the bridge.

Tyler also referenced this track in a numerous tweets[1][2] before the album released.

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1128345413822500864

The song features Jessy Wilson and Santigold.

https://twitter.com/tylerthecreator/status/1130136278115201026

songs.title: SMUCKERS

description.plain:
After the tracklist dropped, this song was the most hyped in hip-hop circles. Tyler claims he made the beat for the first part of the song in 2011 for Watch The Throne, but he took the track back to keep for himself.

Tyler has collaborated with both artists before, but never together, and never with either on one of his own records. He featured on Game’s song “Martian vs Goblins” with Lil Wayne in 2011, and performed live with Kanye at 2013’s Camp Flog Gnaw in Los Angeles.

Yeezy & Weezy have previously collaborated on “Barry Bonds”, “See You In My Nightmares”, “Lollipop (Remix)”, “Swagga Like Us”, & “Forever”.

songs.full_title: FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Charlie Wilson, Kali Uchis, Syd & Toro y Moi)
songs.title: FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT
songs.title_with_featured: FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT (Ft. Charlie Wilson, Kali Uchis, Syd & Toro y Moi)

description.plain:
“FUCKING YOUNG” explores Tyler falling in love with a girl six years younger than him. The second half, “PERFECT,” is a duet with Kali Uchis.

The narrative of the song incorporates Tyler’s album title Cherry Bomb as an allusion to the song written by Joan Jett and the Runaways by the same name.  Just like the questionably young female that Tyler is perplexed by in “FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT,” The Runaways' song establishes the phrase “cherry bomb” as meaning female jailbait; as stated by Songfacts:

In the context of the Runaways' song, [cherry bomb] means an underage girl who is lots of trouble – in this case taunting her parents and other adults with suggestions of promiscuity and bad behavior.

The song’s title represents feelings from both Tyler and this girl. Tyler says she’s too “Fucking Young” while the girl thinks Tyler’s “Perfect.” The emotions from both people correlate with both parts of the song.

This track also continues the trend of the tenth track on each of Tyler’s albums featuring multiple songs (usually about a girl) stitched together:



Bastard: “VCR / Wheels”


Goblin: “Fish / Boppin' Bitch”


Wolf: “PartyIsntOver/Campfire/Bimmer”


Cherry Bomb: “FUCKING YOUNG / PERFECT”


Flower Boy: “911 / Mr. Lonely”


IGOR: “GONE, GONE / THANK YOU”




Tyler isn’t the only rapper in L.A. going through relationship angst with someone under-age.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SCcVrLcGD7k

The music video ends with a scene of Tyler and friends driving around in a wide-open desert, featuring an aesthetic that is reminiscent of the 1985 film Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome, which in turn inspired the music video for 2Pac’s “California Love”; either would make sense for an homage from Tyler.

The second half, “PERFECT,” recently received a visual with an extended version with Austin Feinstein:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XIqVCJWSoeE&index=172&list=FLrVEo1OR_j27b41PLEjARLQ

songs.full_title: I THINK by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: I THINK

description.plain:
“I THINK” questions both Tyler’s mental state and his feelings in a romantic relationship. Tyler doesn’t know whether to continue to be vulnerable, because of his partner’s actions and their effect on Tyler, but his curiosity grows and latches on to the bond he has created with this person. This pushes him to believe in love. This develops the theme of love throughout the album, as introduced in the previous track.

Tyler released “a fraction of” the music video for the track on October 24th, 2019.

songs.full_title: GONE, GONE / THANK YOU by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: GONE, GONE / THANK YOU

description.plain:
“GONE, GONE / THANK YOU” is the tenth song on IGOR, and follows the multi-part structure that all of his tenth tracks have followed since Bastard.

The chorus of the “GONE, GONE” samples “Hey Girl” by Cullen Omori. “THANK YOU” heavily interpolates the lyrics and melody from “Fragile” by Tatsuro Yamashita, an influential city pop artist from Japan.

“GONE, GONE” features Tyler thinking about losing his love for his partner that has been discussed throughout the album, while “THANK YOU” features Tyler thanking his partner for their love.

songs.full_title: Goblin by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: Goblin

description.plain:
The opening titular track from Tyler The Creator’s Goblin album, his follow up to Bastard.

The raps are inter-cut with dialogue between Tyler and his therapist/alter-ego/conscience Dr. TC. In the song and in these conversations, Tyler is talking to himself, trying to work out issues that he has with his life, public image, etc.

description.plain:
“Boredom” is the 8th track on Flower Boy. The song was released as the third official single on the 11th of July 2017. It features vocals from Anna of the North, Corinne Bailey Rae and Rex Orange County and guitar work by Austin Feinstein of Slow Hollows – as confirmed by Tyler on Twitter.

The song is similar in tone and topic to that of many songs on Flower Boy. The song largely focuses on the state of loneliness. Tyler reaches the deep pockets of this state in his elaborate verses.

songs.full_title: A BOY IS A GUN* by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: A BOY IS A GUN*

description.plain:
“A BOY IS A GUN*” is one of the more Kanye-esque tracks out of IGOR, as seen by Tyler’s delivery of the chorus and the clear use of “Bound” by the Ponderosa Twins, which was also sampled by West in his 2013 album, Yeezus. The song was first teased in a 28-second snippet posted by Tyler on May 13, 2019. It is one of the softer cuts on the album with the chorus featuring prominent use of a soul sample, with glittery synths and keys littered throughout the background.

Tyler seems to be alluding to his possible bisexuality, with the lyrical similes of his lover being like a gun and the title of the track being “A BOY IS A GUN*.” Throughout the song, Tyler compares being with his love interest with gun ownership in several ways.

The title “A BOY IS A GUN*” was inspired by the 1971 French western movie A Girl Is a Gun which Tyler confirmed at the IGOR Apple Music concert.

The song’s music video was released on September 16th, 2019.

songs.full_title: Garden Shed by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Estelle)
songs.title: Garden Shed

description.plain:
On “Garden Shed,” Tyler uses the titular imagery as an extended metaphor for keeping one’s sexual orientation concealed, more commonly referred to as being “in the closet.” Although it’s unclear whether or not he is actually coming out, he does directly address the notion in the second verse.

In the past, Tyler has hinted at his sexual orientation with drawings, tweets, and lyrics, but here he takes on a more explicit and serious tone. The song is assisted by British R&B singer Estelle, who has voiced her support of the LGBT+ community.

songs.full_title: Colossus by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: Colossus

description.plain:
The song is named after the roller coaster Colossus at Six Flags Magic Mountain in Valencia, California.

This is Tyler’s take on dealing with a crazed fan – essentially his version of Eminem’s “Stan”.

That said, comparisons to Eminem’s classic draw Tyler’s ire. Regardless, he did go on to state they are both good songs.

https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/324615488208506880

https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/324616073859190786

It’s based on a true story too.

https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/333357309860380672

There is actually a second version of the song Colossus, it was Live at the Odd Future carnival, it is actually the Original version of the song.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p12FxF_gQxI

songs.full_title: PUPPET by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: PUPPET

description.plain: “PUPPET” is the second collaboration between Tyler, the Creator and Kanye West, the first being on “SMUCKERS” from Cherry Bomb. The track discusses the obsessive and protective nature of being in love, and how controlling it can be. Here Tyler/IGOR acknowledges both the positive and negative sides of being under your lover’s thumb. This is thematically represented in the disjointed second half of the song, where music from the start of the song abruptly cuts in.

songs.full_title: IGOR'S THEME by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: IGOR’S THEME

description.plain:
“IGOR’S THEME,” the introductory track to the project, was first teased in a 50-second snippet posted on Tyler’s social media platforms on May 1, 2019, shortly after  speculation arose surrounding the album after the release of a Sony Financial Report. The track also features additional guest vocals from Lil Uzi Vert and Solange.

Tyler uses this track primarily to let the listener know what they are getting into by indulging in this album, and that they will indeed, “feel this one,” if they weren’t expecting to do so already. The track opens with a distorted bass playing one note for 24 seconds. This same bass sound reappears in some shape or form on every song on the album.

songs.full_title: PartyIsntOver/Campfire/Bimmer by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Frank Ocean & Lætitia Sadier)
songs.title: PartyIsntOver/Campfire/Bimmer

description.plain:
On Valentine’s Day 2013,  Tyler released the first single for his then-upcoming album Wolf, “Domo 23.” Appended to the end of that music video was a music video for a snippet of another song, “Bimmer”.

https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/302286290483806209

Also if you notice, the tenth track of every Tyler album features two or more songs that are combined together:

Bastard: “VCR/Wheels”
Goblin: “Fish/Boppin' Bitch”
Wolf: “PartyIsntOver/Campfire/Bimmer”
Cherry Bomb: “FUCKING YOUNG/PERFECT”
*Flower Boy:  “911/Mr. Lonely”
IGOR: “GONE, GONE/THANK YOU”

songs.full_title: Sandwitches by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Hodgy)
songs.title: Sandwitches

description.plain:
The song premiered on an October 8th, 2010 post  by The Fader.  It is a general statement of OF’s principles and motivations.

The song was performed on national TV for Late Night with Jimmy Fallon. Pitchfork, for some reason, continues to claim the song is from the MellowHype album BlackenedWhite, an error they made in their original post of the mp3.

And for the hilarious, censored version, come on over here!

songs.title: AssMilk

description.plain:
On this track from Tyler’s album Bastard, Tyler and friend/brother/OF member Earl Sweatshirt put on a back and forth lyrical showcase of typical Tyler/Earl topics and themes (rape, murder, pop culture references)

On all of Earl’s parts, the beat is fairly light. When Tyler comes in, the beat switches to a more sinister track. Though they both get nasty, this reflects the playfulness of Earl’s evil and the aggressive cruelty of Tyler’s

The title is likely a dig at music site Earmilk

Check out Earl’s live NYC performance – his first concert since freedom!

songs.full_title: WHAT'S GOOD by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: WHAT’S GOOD

description.plain:
“WHAT’S GOOD” is the ninth track from Tyler’s fifth studio album IGOR. It was first teased in a 48-second snippet posted on Tyler’s social media platforms on May 3, 2019, showing him dancing frantically to the song.

The track makes heavy use of drums and distorted synths, one of the more aggressive cuts from the album. It is also one of the only tracks that Tyler raps throughout.

Up-and-coming UK rapper slowthai, who also released an album on May 17, provides additional vocals for the track.

songs.full_title: November by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: November

description.plain:
On the twelfth track of Flower Boy, Tyler depicts his insecurities and fears concerning his life, career, and relationships, reminiscing of the past in a nostalgic fashion.

Split by an interlude of scattered voices, the first part of this track elaborates on his material worries  while the second half details a crush that serves as a setup for the next song, “Glitter”.

In the days before Flower Boy, Tyler would often hint at lines from this track, such as in his Twitter bio or in the form of tweets:

songs.full_title: RUNNING OUT OF TIME by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: RUNNING OUT OF TIME

description.plain:
“RUNNING OUT OF TIME” describes Tyler’s fleeting relationship with a significant other and warn them that a split is imminent.

Thematically, it introduces tension to the love dynamic previously constructed throughout the album.

During Tyler’s Apple Music Concert in L.A, he explained that he showed the album to Kendrick Lamar, where Kendrick praised him about the raw feeling of the album and his overall willingness to ‘sing his truth’. This conversation led him to write this song.

songs.full_title: Where This Flower Blooms by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Frank Ocean)
songs.title: Where This Flower Blooms
songs.title_with_featured: Where This Flower Blooms (Ft. Frank Ocean)

description.plain:
This is the second track off of Tyler’s fourth studio album, Flower Boy.

The first verse focuses on how Tyler used to live before making it big: counting sheep and being too broke to have the cars he “only dreamed I could afford,” which he now owns.

The second and third verse embody the ethos of Flower Boy; growth and expression.

It features Frank Ocean who’s featured on many of Tyler’s songs in the past, most notably “She.” You can also find him on “911 / Mr. Lonely,” the tenth track of Flower Boy.

songs.full_title: OKRA by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: OKRA

description.plain:
“OKRA,” released in late March, was recorded in January before Tyler’s 2018 tour.

He stated, in a tweet (shown below), that around a week before the release, he recorded the music video – which was uploaded on YouTube prior to the song being released on Spotify, Tidal, etc.



It is the first song Tyler has released officially since his fourth studio album Flower Boy, not accounting for the verse he dropped on “After The Storm” with Kali Uchis (as it was a feature) or “ZIPLOC” (as it was not an official release).

On the track, Tyler touches on subjects like his sexuality and the potential end of Odd Future.

songs.title: I Ain’t Got Time!

description.plain:
Throughout “I Ain’t Got Time,” Tyler covers topics ranging from his dismissal of people only interested in him because of his success and his astonishment of what he has accomplished and yearning for more.

On the previous song, the hook repeats “find some time” so this song serves as a contrast to Tyler’s bored state of mind through a shift in lyrics and a more upbeat tempo.

songs.full_title: ARE WE STILL FRIENDS? by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: ARE WE STILL FRIENDS?

description.plain:
“ARE WE STILL FRIENDS” features Tyler, The Creator wrestling the thought of whether or not he and his former lover can remain friends, thematically wrapping up the album and closing out the arc of falling in love, losing that love, trying to convince himself he’s over it, and then bargaining to find some way to have them still in his life. The track combines a funky beat, crooning guitar, and synths with soft singing throughout.

Pharrell Williams has made an appearance on every Tyler record since 2013. He first showed up on “IFHY” off Wolf, he can be heard on the first verse of “KEEP DA O’S” off Cherry Bomb, and he sang on the outro for “Enjoy Right Now, Today” off Flower Boy.

The guitar solo was performed by Jack White. The song samples Al Green’s “Dream,” emulating the keys, guitar, and backing vocals.

songs.full_title: Foreword by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Rex Orange County)
songs.title: Foreword

description.plain: This song “Foreword” serves as an intro to Tyler’s 4th studio album, Flower Boy. A foreword is typically used to set the stage for something before it’s presented, which this song certainly does by exploring Tyler’s motivation and, towards the end of the song, lack of it. He comes to explore suicidal-type thoughts by wondering if anyone would care if he “drowned”, which sets the stage for the rest of the record as an exploration of his inner self.

songs.title_with_featured: WHAT THE FUCK RIGHT NOW (Ft. A$AP Rocky)

description.plain:
Tyler, The Creator teams up with A$AP Rocky for  his own version of Kanye West’s “Freestyle 4,” after Tyler showed his liking of the song. Even though Rocky doesn’t have a verse on the song, he provides many ad-libs, in addition to a spoken intro and outro.

The song was debuted on Thursday, March 3rd, on the official OFWGKTA YouTube account.

The video features Rocky, Tyler and other Odd Future members jumping around a studio while performing the song. It also features a cameo appearance from A$AP Lou.

Post-release, Kanye tweeted his approval:

https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/706615681903628288

songs.full_title: Her by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: Her

description.plain:
On this track, Tyler raps about being excited when the girl he likes texts him back or talks to him.

It is the first time that Tyler shows affection for a girl. Instead of wanting to rape them in fantasy, he gets excited at the idea of dating her, kissing her in the hallway.

Tyler gets hope near the end of the song when it appears she’s about to break up with her dude but it turns out that she got back with him and it pisses Tyler off.

songs.full_title: I DON'T LOVE YOU ANYMORE by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: I DON’T LOVE YOU ANYMORE

description.plain:
“I DON’T LOVE YOU ANYMORE” is seemingly about Tyler no longer being in love with this person and finally getting over them, but it’s actually Tyler just pretending and lying to himself, because he was hurt. He does this a few times on the album.

The high pitched voice shows that all the anger he expresses through the words is like the overblown anger of a child; no matter how many times he says he doesn’t love them anymore it won’t make it true.

On the previous track, “GONE, GONE / THANK YOU” Tyler seemingly accepts the loss of this person and he never wants to fall in love again, but that is only because of how hurt he is.

On “I DON’T LOVE YOU ANYMORE” Tyler says that he is no longer in love and is completely over it, yet he still chases this love (to an extent) on the last track ARE WE STILL FRIENDS? where he finally admits that he can’t let go, with even the final two lines of the album being:

Can’t say goodbye

Tyler clearly still has deep feelings for this person, even though he pretended like he didn’t and tried to run away, because he was left scarred. All of this connects back to the track “EXACTLY WHAT YOU RUN FROM YOU END UP CHASING”.

songs.full_title: Pigs by Tyler, The Creator
songs.title: Pigs

description.plain:
The song talks about why Sam (a character in the album) is so fucked up. It’s due to bullying – something that Tyler’s hero Eminem talked about also.

https://twitter.com/fucktyler/status/325705747038101504

Note that this song is titled, “Pigs,” and the album is titled, “Wolf.” This could be in reference to the story, The Three Little Pigs.

songs.full_title: Pothole by Tyler, The Creator (Ft. Jaden)
songs.title: Pothole

description.plain: On the sixth song on Flower Boy, Tyler diverts from the theme of love and longing to discusses obstacles in his life using the metaphor of driving. Driving is a common motif in the beginning of the album, and the “pothole” is something in life attempting to get Tyler “stuck” and keep him from moving forward.
